Research Paper Sustainable Aerobic Transamidation and Esterification of N-Heteroaryl Amides by Heterogeneous Copper Catalyst Narina Wang Software Methodology Investigation Chaolumen Bai Writing – original draft Data curation Xiaomin Ge Writing – original draft Software Dan Liu Resources Data curation Agula Bao Software Conceptualization Tegshi Muschin Data curation Yong-Sheng Bao Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ College of Chemistry and Environmental Science, Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Green catalysis, Inner Mongolia Normal University, Hohhot, 010022, China College of Chemistry and Environmental Science Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Green catalysis Inner Mongolia Normal University Hohhot 010022 China College of Chemistry and Environmental Science, Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Green catalysis, Inner Mongolia Normal University, Hohhot, 010022, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Transamidation of secondary amides via heterogeneous strategy has remained an unsolved problem. Here we report a novel and efficient approach for transamidation and esterification of ubiquitous N-heteroaryl amides with various amines and alcohols that exploits an engineered heterogeneous supported copper nanoparticles catalyst. This method overcomes the difficulty of heterogeneous catalysts, which can only achieve transamidation of primary amide driven by the emission of ammonia gas. A broad diversity of N-heteroaryl amides containing quinolin-2-yl, isoquinolin-1-yl, pyrazin-2-yl and pyridin-2-yl directing groups convert into corresponding α-ketoamides and α-ketoesters using needle-shape copper nanoparticles supported on γ-Al2O3 as heterogeneous catalyst. This environmentally benign, catalyst recyclable and easy-to-handle catalysis methodology will have great application prospects in the pharmaceutical synthesis and biological or chemical industry. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Transamidation Copper nanoparticles C-N bond activation α-ketoamides α-ketoesters Data availability The data supporting this article have been included as part of the Supplementary Information. 1 Introduction Amides are fundamental structural motifs in natural products, pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals [1-3]. Indeed, the amide bond was found in 2/3 of drug candidates in a 2006 survey and was present in 25% of all pharmaceuticals currently on the market [4]. Consequently, the pursuit of green and efficient amidation methods remains a crucial objective in the field of synthetic chemistry [5]. Except for conventional approaches involving the coupling of activated carboxylic acid derivatives with amines, transamidation is a convenient and straightforward method for amide diversification [6-8]. Over the past decades, numerous homogeneous Lewis acid or transition metal-catalyzed transamidation reactions have been developed [9-19]. In the view of green chemistry, recent efforts have been focused on heterogeneous catalyzed transamidation reactions to overcome the limitations of homogeneous catalysis such as difficulties of catalyst separation and recycling as well as environmental pollution. Several heterogeneous catalysts such as HfCl4 supported on KSF-polyDMAP [20], Fe3+-exchanged montmorillonite [21], mesoporous niobium oxide spheres [22], CeO2 [23,24], Fe3O4–CA magnetic nanoparticles [25], Fe3O4-Guanidine acetic acid nanoparticles [26], H-β-zeolite [27] and sulfated tungstate [28] have been used for transamidation reactions (see Scheme 1 a). However, these heterogeneous catalysts can only achieve transamidation of primary amide driven by the emission of ammonia gas. To our knowledge, the heterogeneous catalyzed transamidation of secondary amides, ubiquitous structural elements in peptides, remained an unsolved problem. As dictated by formally planar architecture and lower carbonyl electrophilicity, the secondary amide is deemed to be the most robust and chemically stable amide. Copper nanoparticles (Cu NPs) as particularly attractive catalysts were utilized for diverse reactions including the hydrogenation reduction of aryl azides or unsaturated compounds [29,30], CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [31], CO oxidation [32], selective epoxidation of alkenes with visible light [33], direct synthesis of dimethyl ether from syngas [34] and Ullmann reaction [35] etc. Recently, our group developed a Cu(OAc)2 catalyzed transamidation of N-(3-methyl)pyridyl amides to synthesize α-ketoamides or α-ketoesters in one step [36]. From the viewpoint of a green and environmental perspective, we envisage whether the transamidation of other ubiquitous N-heteroaryl amides can be achieved by environmentally benign, recyclable heterogeneous Cu NPs. Herein, we report, for the first time, a sustainable Cu NPs catalysis system for the transamidation of ubiquitous N-heteroaryl amides using air as a clean oxidant, without adding any additional oxidant, ligand or base (Scheme 1b). In a series of supported Cu NPs, the Cu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with a needle-shape and 3wt% Cu loading exhibited the best catalytic performance and it could be used for seven cycles without significant loss in catalytic activity. Our experiment results illustrated that the chelation-assisted effect of heteroaryl by forming six-membered N, O-chelated metallacycle and the introduction of α-carbonyl group are crucial for the heterogeneous catalyzed transamidation. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Materials All the reagents, including CuCl2, nano metal oxides, NaOH, NaBH4, carboxylic acid, amines and alcohols, were purchased from Aladdin (China) without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst Preparation The Cu NPs on γ-Al2O3 and other supports were prepared by an reported method for the preparation of Pd/γ-Al2O3 [37]. For example, 3wt% Cu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by the following procedure: 0.97 g of γ-Al2O3 powder was suspended in 50 mL of distilled water, followed by adding 47 mL of 0.01 M of CuCl2 aqueous solution and stirred at room temperature. Then 1 mL of 0.03 M of L-Lysine aqueous solution was added into the mixture above, and continuous stirred 10 min. Subsequently, 0.1 M NaOH aqueous solution was added into the mixture to adjust the pH to 7. Whereafter, 4.5 mL of 0.35 M NaBH4 aqueous solution was added dropwise within 10-15 min while vigorous stirring. The mixture was then stirred 40 min and let stand overnight. The solid was separated by centrifuging, washed with distilled water for 2 times and ethanol for 2 times, and dried at 80°C. The dried solid was used directly as the catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization methods The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope employing an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples were suspended in ethanol and dried on holey carbon-coated Cu grids. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on a Thermo-Scientific ESCALAB 250 Xi equipped with an Al Kα (1486.6 eV) X-ray source, for which the charging effect correction was calibrated with C1s (284.8 eV). The specific surface areas of all samples were obtained on a ASAP-2020 accelerated surface area and porosity analyzer of American Micromeritics Company, resulted from the nitrogen sorption data of the samples using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model in a relative pressure (P/P0) range between 0.06 and 0.30. Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) of Cu in the solid samples was performed on Agilent 720. 2.4 Activity Test A mixture of N-(quinolin-2-yl)-amides 1 (0.10 mmol), amines 2 (0.30 mmol), TBAHS (51 mg 0.15 mmol), and 3 wt % Cu/γ-Al2O3 (25 mg) in CH3CN (1.0 mL) was charged in a 25 mL oven-dried reaction tube. The reaction mixture was heated at 90°C in a heating mantle for 18 h until the starting material was consumed (monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC)). The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography (silica gel, ethyl acetate/petroleum ether = 1:3−1:1 as an eluent) to afford the desired product 3. A mixture of N-(quinolin-2-yl)-amides 1 (0.10 mmol), 3 wt % Cu/γ-Al2O3 (25 mg), TBAHS (51 mg 0.15 mmol) and alcohol 4 (3.0 equiv.) was charged in a 25 mL oven-dried reaction tube using DCE (1 mL) or alcohol as solvent. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 18 h at 90°C. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography (silica gel, ethyl acetate/petroleum ether = 1:8−1:3 as an eluent) to afford the desired product 5. 2.5 Catalysts recycle experiment After each reaction cycle, the solvent, substrate, and products were removed by centrifugation; the separated catalyst was washed thoroughly with ethanol (twice) and then distilled water (4 times), followed by centrifugal separation and drying at 80°C for 12 h. The recovered catalyst was used for the next cycle. 2.6 Hot filtration test 1a (0.1 mmol), 2a (3 equiv.), 3 wt % Cu/γ-Al2O3 (25 mg), TBAHS (51 mg 0.15 mmol) and CH3CN (1mL) were added into two reaction tube, respectively. One reaction was ceased after 1 h and the 1a was isolated for calculating turnover number (TON). Another reaction is applied by filtering the reaction mixture through a pre-heated Celite pad after the reaction for 1 h. Then the filtered reaction solution continued to react for 1 h under normal conditions and the 1a was isolated for calculating TON. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1.1 Characterization To have a good knowledge about the catalyst, the fresh and used (recovered after 1st cycle) Cu NPs on γ-Al2O3 catalysts were investigated by TEM, XPS, ICP-OES and so on. The TEM analysis of the fresh and used catalysts was represented in Fig. 1 . Different from Pd NPs supported on γ-Al2O3 [37], the Cu NPs with needle-shape are distributed evenly on the γ-Al2O3 surface. The generating of special needle-shape nanoparticles can be ascribed to that Cu+ or Cu2+, which have similar size to Al3+, tend to diffuse into metal vacancies of the lattice resulting more regular nanoparticle distribution [38]. The mean diameter and length of the Cu nanoneedles for the fresh catalyst were measured and found to be 3.8 nm and 22.5 nm (Fig. 1a). It does not cause an obvious increase in the mean diameter and length of the Cu nanoneedles after 1st cycle (Fig. 1b). As revealed by the EDS mapping image, the Cu, O and Al elements in Cu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are distributed uniformly over the entire sample (Fig. 1c). The (200) lattice plane of Cu2O (0.23 nm) was revealed by the HRTEM, suggesting the Cu NPs with Cu+ state and anchoring on γ-Al2O3 through oxygen bridges (Fig. 1d). In order to understand the valence state of Cu NPs supported on γ-Al2O3, the fresh and used catalysts were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 2 , the binding energies of Cu 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 electrons are 932.8 eV and the binding energies of Cu 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 electrons are 932.8 eV and 952.8 eV for the fresh catalyst and 932.8 eV and 952.9 eV for the used catalyst, respectively, which are close to those of metallic Cu or Cu+ (932.4 and 952.2 eV) [39]. Significantly, the chemical states of Cu did not change obviously after reaction. Combined with the result of HRTEM, it is suggested that Cu+ as the active centre completed the catalytic cycle. The BET analyses were conducted and specific surface areas are given in Table 1 . It cans be seen that the surface area of γ-Al2O3 do not cause obvious change after loading Cu NPs and there is almost no change in the specific surface area of catalyst before andafter reaction. According to the ICP-OES results, Cu loading of 2.06, 1.41, 1.21, 1.25 wt% (± 10% error) were detected in fresh 3wt% Cu/γ-Al2O3 and after 1st, 2nd, and 3th use. Furthermore, the Cu NPs catalyst did not show deactivation in seven runs after centrifugation, washing and drying. As shown in Fig. 3 , the catalytic performance of the Cu NPs catalyst decreased significantly after the first run, but the Cu NPs catalyst showed the excellent stability in the six recycles that followed. So a possible reason for decrease in catalytic activity in recycling experiments is the decrease of Cu content in catalyst. This result is consistent with the ICP-OES results. However, we can't rule out the possibility that the irreversible chelation of N-heteroaryl amides with Cu lead to the decrease of catalytic active sites. To test if the leached Cu is responsible for the reaction, the hot filtration test was executed (see Table 1). The conversion of 1a and TON value indicated that after filtration the substrate turnover ceases and the possibility of homogeneous catalysis could be ruled out. Hence, the slight decrease of Cu loading after the first run may be attributed to that the slight physical adsorbed Cu is washed off in the first washing process. 3.2 Sustainable catalyst screening and reaction scope Our initial attempt was executed toward the Cu NPs catalyzed transamidation of N-(quinolin-2-yl)-2-(o-tolyl)acetamide 1a and aniline 2a using 3wt% Cu/γ-Al2O3 as the catalyst, TBAHS as a additive and acetonitrile as a solvent. To our delight, after 18 h of refluxing the desired α-oxygenated transamidation product 2-oxo-N-phenyl-2-(o-tolyl) acetamide 3aa was obtain in 81% yield (Table 2 , entry 1). Other Cu NPs on different supports including α-Al2O3, Sm2O3, ZnO, ZrO2 and TiO2 were prepared by the same impregnation-reduction method and applied to the model reaction (entries 2-6). These catalysts exhibited slight lower catalytic activity. Additionally, Cu NPs loaded on γ-Al2O3 powder at varying contents (1wt%, 5wt%) were prepared and applied to the model reaction (entries 7,8). It was found that the catalyst with 3wt% Cu exhibited the best catalytic performance. In the light of Ohshima's work [40], other quaternary ammonium salts additives were screened (entries 9,10). TBAHS was identified as the most effective additive. Control experiments showed that the reaction failed to happen in the absence of a copper catalyst or air and the yield of amide 1a was >99% (entry 11,12). In addition, when radical scavengers such as 1,1,5,5-tetramethylpentamethylene nitroxide (TEMPO) was added in the model reaction, the yield of desired product 3aa was significantly decreased (entry 13). These experiment results indicated that the superoxide radical, which comes from the interaction of Cu NPs with O2 [41,42], induced α-carbonyl group to N-quinolinyl amides 1a and promoted next step transamidation process. Having identified optimized conditions, the N-heteroaryl amides substrate scope of this CuNPs catalyzed transamidation was investigated using aniline 2a as an amine source (Scheme 2 ). Generally, the reaction of N-(quinolin-2-yl) phenylacetamides containing electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups proceeded efficiently with moderate to good yields (3aa-3ja). A wide range of functional groups such as alkyl, phenyl, halogen, methylthio and trifluoromethyl were tolerated under the reaction condition. Furthermore, the methyl group at different positions on the arene group did not affect the reaction activity (3aa, 3ca, 3da). The naphthyl acetamide and thienyl acetamide also afforded the desired transamidation products with good yields, greatly expanding the amide substrate scope (3ba, 3ka). Next, other ubiquitous N-heteroaryl amides were examined, a variety of amides containing N-(isoquinolin-1-yl) (1a2 ), N-(5-methylpyrazin-2-yl) (1a4 ), N-(5-phenylpyrazin-2-yl) (1a5 ), N-(pyridin-2-yl) (1a6 ), N-(6-methylpyridin-2-yl) (1a7 ) and N-(3-methylpyridin-2-yl) (1a8 ) group performed the reaction smoothly albeit in lower yields. However, when 1a3 with 8-aminoquinoline group and 1a9 with 4-aminopyridine group were treated with standard reaction conditions, no reaction occurred. These results illustrated that the chelation-assisted effect of N-heteroaryl by forming resonant six-membered N,O-chelated metallacycle is a key for the Cu NPs catalyzed transamidation, as same as homogeneous catalysis [36]. When N-(3-methylpyridin-2-yl)-3-phenylpropanamide 1a10 was used as substrate, no reaction occurred. This indicated that containing highly active α-H (both α-H of benzyl and acyl group) is essential for the Cu NPs catalyzed aerobic transamidation reaction. The scope of the Cu NPs catalyzed aerobic transamidation leading to α-ketoamides was further expanded to a variety of amines using 2-(naphthalen-2-yl)-N-(quinolin-2-yl)acetamide 1b as amide source (Scheme 3 ). The reactions of various aromatic amines, aliphatic primary amines and secondary amines proceeded well with moderate to excellent yields. The Cu NPs catalyzed transamidation afforded α-ketoamides in moderate to good yields irrespective of the position of substituents on the benzene ring and electronic nature of the aromatic amines (3bb-3bh). Likewise, the apparent steric hindrance effect was not detected in linear (3bj, 3bk) and branched (3bl-3bn) primary amines. Morpholine as a secondary amine underwent the transamidation reaction effectively to afford the desired α-ketoamide in the best yield (3bo). More than that, the reaction can be scale up to gram-scale affording 3bo in 77% yield, demonstrated the potential application of the heterogeneous catalysis in the chemical industry. To expand the application of the heterogeneous Cu NPs catalyzed transamidation reaction, we evaluated the scope of the methodology with respect to alcohols which are relatively weak nucleophiles (Scheme 4 ). A variety of primary and secondary aliphatic alcohols reacted smoothly with 1b to generate corresponding α-ketoesters in moderate to good yields (5ba-5bh). The reaction generality was further probed by various natural alcohols such as furfuryl alcohol, menthol, (–)-borneol, nerol and cholesterol, which performed the reaction effectively to give the natural alcohol derivatives in moderate yields (5bi-5bm). Using methanol as both reagent and solvent, N-quinolyl phenyl acetamides tolerated a wide variety of functional groups and showed good reactivity to give the corresponding α-ketoesters (5aa-5pa). The reaction is free from the influence of the electronic and steric nature of the benzene ring of amides. N-quinolyl naphthyl acetamide performed the Cu NPs catalyzed aerobic transamidation reaction expediently to give the corresponding α-ketoester in 77% yield. Based on previous reports [36], a proposed mechanism for this α-oxygenated tramsamidation of secondary amides is illustrated in Scheme 5 . Firstly, the secondary amide 1 coordinates with heterogeneous copper(I) catalyst to form six-membered N,O-chelated copper cycle intermediate A with the hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) to support. Subsequently, intermediate A combined with molecular dioxygen in air to generate a peroxycopper(II) radical B which undergoes an intramolecular 1,6-HAT process to afford benzyl radical species C. Next, hydrogen peroxide radical which is generated from homolytic cleavage of the O-Cu coordination bond was recombined with the benzyl radical to give intermediate D. Thus, the important intermediate α-carbonyl species E can be obtained smoothly by C-H bond oxygenation accompanied with elimination a molecule of water. The newly generated acyl group will further enhance the electrophilic reactivity of the amide group, thus benefiting the attack of amine 2. Finally, the desired transamidation product 3 and active heterogeneous copper(I) catalyst are generated from F with the assistance of water to complete the catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusions We have shown for the first time the sustainable aerobic transamidation of ubiquitous secondary amides on Cu nanoparticles anchored on aluminum oxide support. In a series of supported Cu NPs, the Cu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with a needle-shape and 3wt% Cu loading exhibited the best catalytic performance and it could be used for seven cycles without significant loss in catalytic activity. This heterogeneous catalysis method features a remarkably broad substrate scope that ranges from ubiquitous N-heteroaryl amides, primary/secondary amines and alcohols to complex natural alcohols and an excellent tolerance of sensitive functional groups. This environmentally benign, catalyst recyclable and easy-to-handle synthetic methodology opens up a new and efficient transamidation route for the secondary amides, which are ubiquitous in peptides. coredata.dc:description: Transamidation of secondary amides via heterogeneous strategy has remained an unsolved problem. Here we report a novel and efficient approach for transamidation and esterification of ubiquitous N-heteroaryl amides with various amines and alcohols that exploits an engineered heterogeneous supported copper nanoparticles catalyst. This method overcomes the difficulty of heterogeneous catalysts, which can only achieve transamidation of primary amide driven by the emission of ammonia gas. A broad diversity of N-heteroaryl amides containing quinolin-2-yl, isoquinolin-1-yl, pyrazin-2-yl and pyridin-2-yl directing groups convert into corresponding α-ketoamides and α-ketoesters using needle-shape copper nanoparticles supported on γ-Al2O3 as heterogeneous catalyst. This environmentally benign, catalyst recyclable and easy-to-handle catalysis methodology will have great application prospects in the pharmaceutical synthesis and biological or chemical industry.
